revision.text:
{{Other uses}} [[File:SplitRockFogSignal.jpg|thumb|right|Building housing the two diaphone foghorns at [[Split Rock Light]].]] A '''foghorn''' is a fog signal that uses sound to warn vehicles of navigational hazards like rocky coastlines, or boats of the presence of other vessels, in [[fog]]gy conditions. The term is most often used in relation to marine transport. When visual [[navigation]] aids such as [[lighthouse]]s are obscured, foghorns provide an audible warning of [[rock outcrop]]s, [[shoal]]s, [[headlands and bays|headlands]], or other dangers to shipping.
==Description== All foghorns use a vibrating column of air to create an audible tone, but the method of setting up this vibration differs. Some horns, like the Daboll trumpet, used vibrating plates or metal [[reed (music)|reeds]], a similar principle to a modern electric [[Vehicle horn|car horn]]. Others used air forced through holes in a revolving cylinder or disk, in the same manner as a [[siren (noisemaker)|siren]]. Semi-automatic operation of foghorns was achieved by using a [[clockwork]] mechanism (or "coder") to sequentially open the valves admitting air to the horns; each horn was given its own timing characteristics to help mariners identify them.<ref name=ayre>See for example Fox, F. [http://homepages.manx.net/fredd/siren.html Siren, Point of Ayre Lighthouse] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709040136/http://homepages.manx.net/fredd/siren.html |date=2008-07-09 }}, accessed 08-09-2008</ref>
==History== ===Early fog signals=== [[File:Fort point light station bell.jpg|thumb|right|An early form of fog signal. The fog bell at [[Fort Point Light Station]], [[Maine]].]] Audible fog signals have been used in one form or another for hundreds of years, initially simply [[Bell (instrument)|bells]] or [[gong]]s struck manually.
At some [[lighthouse]]s, a small [[cannon]] was let off periodically to warn away ships, but this had the obvious disadvantage of having to be fired manually throughout the whole period the fog persisted (which could be for several days). Lighthouse windows and lighting apparatus were susceptible to damage depending on the proximity of the explosion.<ref>{{cite book |last=Oke |first=Robert |date=15 May 1863|title= Letter to J. H. Warren Esq. Chairman, Board of Works (St. John’s); Letters by Robert Oke (1794-1870) |location= PANL GN 1/3/A file 1/1864 |publisher=The Rooms Archives (St. John’s, NL) }}</ref> One incident of lax handling of explosives nearby resulted in a concussion that propelled the lighthouse keeper at [http://lighthousefriends.com/light.asp?ID=1312/ Fort Amherst], who was seated, to the other end of the room.<ref>{{cite book |last=Oke |first=Robert |date=5 Jan 1863|title= Letter to J. H. Warren Esq. Chairman Board of Works (St. John’s); Letters by Robert Oke (1794-1870) |location= PANL File 1/1864 |publisher=The Rooms Archives (St. John’s, NL) }}</ref> In the [[United States]], [[whistle]]s were also used where a source of steam power was available, though [[Trinity House]], the [[United Kingdom|British]] [[lighthouse authority]], did not employ them, preferring an explosive signal.
Throughout the 19th century efforts were made to automate the signalling process. Trinity House eventually developed a system (the "[[Signal, Fog, Mk I]]") for firing a [[nitrocellulose|gun-cotton]] charge electrically. However, the charge had to be manually replaced after each signal. At [[Portland Bill]], for example, which had a five-minute interval between fog-signals, this meant the horns had to be lowered, the two new charges inserted, and the horns raised again every five minutes during foggy periods. Clockwork systems were also developed for striking bells.<ref name=pepper>Pepper, T. ''[http://www.terrypepper.com/lights/closeups/fogsignal/stevens/stevens.htm Stevens Fog Bell Apparatus]'', Seeing the Light</ref>
Captain [[James William Newton]] claimed to have been the inventor of the fog signalling technique using loud and low notes.<ref name=jesmond>{{cite web |work=[[Jesmond Old Cemetery]] |url=http://www.jesmondoldcemetery.co.uk/newton_50.html |title=James William Newton |quote=[[James William Newton|Captain Newton]] also claimed to be the inventor of fog signalling by the interchange and repetition [sic] of loud and low notes.}}</ref>
===Mechanization=== [[File:Foghorns.jpg|thumb|right|Foghorns near [[Lizard Point, Cornwall|Lizard Point]], [[Cornwall]]. This installation uses a [[siren (noisemaker)|siren]] to produce sound.]] [[File:Foghorn building on Flat Holm Island.jpg|thumb|right|Another Trinity House fog siren installation on [[Flat Holm]], now restored by the Flat Holm Project]][[File:SumburgLighthouseFoghorn.jpg|thumb|right|Bearing mechanism of [[Sumburgh Head|Sumburgh]] lighthouse Foghorn ([[Shetland]])]]
The first [[Automation|automated]] [[steam]]-powered foghorn was invented by [[Robert Foulis (inventor)|Robert Foulis]], a Scotsman who emigrated to [[Saint John, New Brunswick|Saint John]], [[New Brunswick]], Canada. Foulis is said to have heard his daughter playing the [[piano]] in the distance on a foggy night, and noticed the low notes were more audible than the higher notes: he then designed a device to produce a low-frequency sound, as well as a code system for use with it. Foulis repeatedly presented his concept to the Commissioners of Light Houses for the [[Bay of Fundy]] for installation on [[Partridge Island, New Brunswick|Partridge Island]]. While the Commissioners initially rejected Foulis's plan, one commissioner eventually encouraged Foulis to submit detailed plans to the Commission. For reasons unknown, the plans were given to another Canadian engineer, [[T. T. Vernon Smith]], who officially submitted them to the Commissioners as his own. The foghorn was constructed at [[Partridge Island, New Brunswick|Partridge Island]] in 1859 as the Vernon-Smith horn. After protest by Foulis and a legislative inquiry, Foulis was credited as the true inventor, but he never patented or profited from his invention.<ref name=foulis>[http://www.glasgowguide.co.uk/info-fame_Robert_Foulis_Jr.html Famous Glaswegians - Robert Foulis, JR], accessed 05-09-08</ref>
The development of fog signal technology continued apace at the end of the 19th century.<ref>[http://www.terrypepper.com/lights/closeups/fogsignal/diaphone/diaphone.htm Terry Pepper, ''Seeing the Light'', "Diaphones".]</ref> During the same period an inventor, [[Celadon Leeds Daboll]], developed a coal-powered foghorn called the [[Daboll trumpet]] for the American lighthouse service, though it was not universally adopted.<ref name=holland>Holland, F. R. ''America's Lighthouses'', Dover, 1988, {{ISBN|0-486-25576-X}}, p. 204</ref> A few Daboll trumpets remained in use until the mid-20th century.
In the [[United Kingdom]], experiments to develop more effective foghorns were carried out by [[John Tyndall]] and [[Lord Rayleigh]], amongst others. The latter's ongoing research for Trinity House culminated in a design for a siren with a large trumpet designed to achieve maximum sound propagation (see reference for details of the Trials of Fog Signals<ref name="Renton 1">{{cite book|last=Renton|first=Alan|title=Lost Sounds: The Story of Coast Fog Signals|year=2001|publisher=Whittles Publishing|isbn=978-1870325837}}</ref>), installed in [[Trevose Head Lighthouse]], [[Cornwall]] in 1913.
One of the first automated fog bells was the Stevens Automatic Bell Striker.<ref>[http://www.terrypepper.com/lights/closeups/fogsignal/stevens/stevens.htm Terry Pepper, Seeing the Light, Stevens Automated Bell Striker.]</ref>
Some later fog bells were placed under water, particularly in especially dangerous areas, so that their sound (which would be a predictable code, such as the number "23") would be carried further and reverberate through the ship's hull. For example, this technique was used at [[White Shoal Light (Michigan)]].<ref name = "National Geographic">{{cite journal |last=Putnam |first= George R. |date=January 1913 |title= Beacons of the Seas: Lighting the Coasts of the United States |journal=National Geographic Magazine |volume=XXIV |issue=1 |pages=19 |id= |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=LNQKAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover#PPA19,M1 |accessdate=June 8, 2009 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.terrypepper.com/lights/michigan/whiteshoal/whiteshoal.htm Terry Pepper, ''Seeing The Light'', White Shoal Light.]</ref> This was an earlier precursor to [[RACON]].
===Diaphone=== {{Main|Diaphone}} From the early 20th century an improved device called the [[diaphone]], originally invented as an [[organ stop]] by [[Robert Hope-Jones]],<ref name="Renton 1"/> and developed as a fog signal by John Northey of [[Toronto]], became the standard foghorn apparatus for new installations.{{where|date=April 2015}} Diaphones were powered by [[compressed air]] and could emit extremely powerful low-frequency notes.
In 1982, the Dutch broadcaster [[VPRO]] aired a live foghorn concert on national radio, relaying the sound of the foghorns in [[Emden]], [[Calais]], [[Nieuwpoort, Belgium|Nieuwpoort]], [[Scheveningen]], [[Den Helder]], [[Lelystad]], [[Urk]], [[Marken]] and [[Kornwerderzand]], mixed with studio music by sound artist [[Alvin Curran]]. <ref>[http://weblogs.vpro.nl/radioarchief/2010/07/22/ovt-serie-gouden-jaren-afl-4-bijzondere-experimenten/#more-4146], retrieved July 26, 2010. Contains an audio file of the complete broadcast. [https://www.nporadio1.nl/ovt/onderwerpen/2483-vpro-radioarchief-experimenten-het-misthoornconcert], retrieved September 6, 2018. Diaphone foghorns are currently still active on Low Head, Souter, whitefish, and Portland Bill, and Whitby Lighouses, for example.</ref>
===Obsolescence=== [[File:Foghorn On Ailsa Craig.jpg|thumb|right|Foghorn on [[Ailsa Craig]], where the fog signal was discontinued in 1966.]] Since automation of lighthouses became common in the 1960s and 1970s, most older foghorn installations have been removed to avoid the need to run the complex machinery associated with them, and have been replaced with electrically powered diaphragm or [[air horn|compressed air horn]]s. Activation is completely automated: a laser or photo beam is shot out to sea, and if the beam reflects back to the source (i.e. the laser beam is visible due to the fog), the sensor sends a signal to activate the foghorn. In many cases, modern navigational aids have rendered large, long-range foghorns completely unnecessary, according to the [[International Association of Lighthouse Authorities]].<ref name=iala>Noble, D. L. ''Lighthouses and Keepers'', Naval Institute Press, 2004, {{ISBN|978-1-59114-626-1}}, p.169</ref>
==Railway fog signals== {{Main|Detonator (railway)}} Fog signals have also been used on railway lines since the middle of the 19th century to indicate to the driver of a moving train that a broken down train, a work party, or some other unforeseen hazard is on the line ahead. Small [[explosive]] [[detonator]]s or torpedoes are placed on the track, and detonated by the pressure of the wheels of the oncoming train. The loud report of the explosion provides the indication to the driver, that in most cases requires the train to be stopped immediately. During [[World War II]], these devices were modified to detonate [[demolition charge]]s during railroad [[sabotage]] operations.
==See also== {{Portal|Nautical}} * [[Siren (noisemaker)]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Foghorns}} {{wsPSM|The Atmosphere in Relation to Fog-Signaling I|6|March 1875}} * [http://www.postcard.org/foghorn.htm Listen to Golden Gate Bridge foghorn] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061126203244/http://www.sanpedro.com/spcom/foghorn.htm a list of foghorn clips from San Pedro, CA.]- Foghorn 1 is a good example of a diaphone. * [http://www.terrypepper.com/lights/closeups/fogsignal/index.htm Terry Pepper, ''Seeing the Light'', "Fog Signal Technology."] * [http://www.sonicwonders.org/?p=468 Location of foghorns that can still be heard in UK] * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00yqp5z BBC Radio 4 - The Foghorn: A Celebration]
{{Lighthouses}}
[[Category:Navigation]] [[Category:Canadian inventions]] [[Category:Aids to navigation]] [[Category:Lighthouse fixtures]]

The '''gross reproduction rate''' ('''GRR''') is the average number of daughters a woman would have if she survived all of her childbearing years, which is roughly to the age of 45, subject to the age-specific fertility rate and sex ratio at birth throughout that period. This rate is a measure of replacement fertility if mortality is not in the equation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/gross+reproduction+rate|title=gross reproduction rate|work=TheFreeDictionary.com|access-date=2017-04-05}}</ref> It is often regarded as the extent to which the generation of daughters replaces the preceding generation of women and so on and so forth. If the value is equal to one that indicates that women will replace themselves. If the value is more than one that indicates that the next generation of women will outnumber the current one. If the value is less than one that indicates that the next generation of women will be less numerous than the current one.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Population: An introduction to Concepts and Issues|last=Weeks|first=John R.|publisher=Cengage Learning|year=2014|isbn=978-1-305-09450-5|location=Boston, MA|pages=227-228}}</ref>
The gross reproduction rate is similar to the [[net reproduction rate]] (NRR), the average number of daughters a woman would have if she survived her lifetime subject to the age-specific fertility rate and mortality rate throughout that period.<ref name=":0" />
GRR=TFR*K Where K=no.of female birth. _________________ Total birth
== See also == * [[Net reproduction rate]] * [[Total fertility rate]] * [[Sub-replacement fertility]]
== References == {{Reflist|refs=http://www.prb.org/Publications/Lesson-Plans/Glossary.aspx}}
[[Category:Human geography]] [[Category:Fertility]] [[Category:Demographic economics]] [[Category:Population statistics]] [[Category:Demographics]]
{{statistics-stub}}

The '''Hans Egede medal''' is awarded by the Royal Danish Geographical Society for outstanding services to geography, "principally for geographical studies and research in the Polar lands." It was instituted in 1916 and named after [[Hans Egede]], a Danish missionary who established a mission in Greenland.<ref> {{cite web|url=https://tidsskrift.dk/index.php/geografisktidsskrift/article/view/4567/8563|title=EGEDE MEDAILLEN |publisher= Royal Danish Geographical Society|accessdate= 30 November 2016}} </ref>
==Recipients== Source: [https://tidsskrift.dk/index.php/geografisktidsskrift/article/view/4567/8563 Royal Danish Geographical Society] * 1921: [[Peter Freuchen]] ; [[Godfred Hansen]] ; [[Morten P. Porsild]] * 1924: [[Knud Rasmussen]] * 1925: [[Roald Amundsen]] * 1927: [[Lauge Koch]] * 1932: [[Gino Watkins|Henry George Watkins]] ; [[Therkel Mathiassen]] * 1933: [[Ejnar Mikkelsen]] ; [[Kaj Birket-Smith]] * 1937: [[Hans Wilhelmsson Ahlmann]] * 1947: [[Pálmi Hannesson]] * 1951: [[Eigil Knuth]] * 1955: [[Helge Larsen]] * 1959: [[Vivian Fuchs]] * 1960: [[Paul A. Siple]] * 1971: [[Willi Dansgaard]] ; [[Børge Fristrup]] * 1976: [[Knud Ellitsgaard-Rasmussen]] ; [[Jørgen Meldgaard]] * 1980: [[Bent Fredskild]] * 1982: [[Gunnar Østrem]] * 1984: [[Trevor Lloyd (geographer)|Trevor Lloyd]] * 1986: [[Preben Gudmandsen]] * 1992: [[Niels Steen Gundestrup]] * 1996: [[Bent Hasholt]] ; [[Johannes Krüger]] * 2017: Bo Elberling <ref> {{cite web|url=https://dg.dk/en/2017/12/21/head-of-center-bo-elberling-receives-the-hans-egede-medal/|title=Head of Center Bo Elberling receives the Hans Egede Medal|publisher=Danish National Research Foundation|accessdate= 20 July 2018}} </ref>, ''for his contributions to research on the Arctic''
==See also== * [[List of prizes, medals and awards]] * [[Prizes named after people]]
==References== {{reflist}} *Article based in part on Hans Egede Medaillen article in Danish Wiki
{{DEFAULTSORT:Egede Medal}} [[Category:Geography awards]] [[Category:Danish awards]] [[Category:Awards established in 1916]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Hong Kong]]; added [[Category:Professional associations based in Hong Kong]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Notability|Org|date=April 2017}} {{Primary sources|date=April 2017}} {{COI|date=April 2017}} {{Tone|date=April 2017}} }} {{Chinese|title=The Hong Kong Institute of Surveyors|t=香港測量師學會|s=香港测量师学会|j=hoeng1 gong2 cak1 loeng4 si1 hok6 wui6*2|p=Xiānggǎng Cèliángshī Xuéhuì}} The '''Hong Kong Institute of Surveyors''' ('''HKIS'''; {{zh|first=t|t=香港測量師學會}}) is a surveying organization in [[Hong Kong]].
It was formally established in April 1984 with 85 founding members. It is the only professional surveying body incorporated by ordinance in Hong Kong. As of February 2017, membership exceeds 9,776, with more than 6,288 corporate members. The first president of the institute was Sr Kan Fook-Yee ({{zh|first=t|t=簡福飴|s=简福饴|j=gaan2 fuk1 ji4|p=Jiǎn Fúyí|labels=no}}).<ref>http://www.cpjobs.com/hk/article/founding-president-the-hkis-kan-fook-yee-played-key-role-helping-hong-kong%E2%80%99s-surveyors</ref><!--Chinese name from http://www.hkis.org.hk/ufiles/HKIS_past.pdf-->
Members holding HKIS qualifications may use the following designations after their name: MHKIS (Member), FHKIS (Fellow), AMHKIS (Associate Member). Those with the designation MHKIS or FHKIS are also known as professional surveyors.
== History ==
Sr Kan Fook-Yee and a number of his colleagues saw the value of a professional body for local surveyors, and the need to stimulate the development of the industry.
Prior to the establishment of the HKIS in 1984, the Britain-based [[Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors]] (RICS) represented the industry in Hong Kong.<ref name=Langdonp106>Langdon, Davis. ''Spon's Asia-Pacific Construction Costs Handbook, Fourth Edition''. [[CRC Press]], March 30, 2010. {{ISBN|0203855345}}, 9780203855348. p. [https://books.google.com.hk/books?id=fiLcnAhinBMC&pg=PA106 106].</ref>
The Institute was statutorily incorporated by virtue of the Hong Kong Institute of Surveyors Ordinance in January 1990 (Cap. 1148). In July 1991, the Surveyors Registration Ordinance (Cap. 417) was passed and a Registration Board was set up to administer the registration of surveyors.<ref>http://www.legislation.gov.hk/blis_pdf.nsf/6799165D2FEE3FA94825755E0033E532/3FE760D395AE8F70482575EF0026CB9B?OpenDocument&bt=0</ref>
The Hong Kong Institute of Surveyors Ordinance of 1990 incorporated the HKIS.<ref name="SiuKup287">Siu, Helen F. and Agnes S. Ku. ''Hong Kong Mobile: Making a Global Population''. [[Hong Kong University Press]], February 1, 2009. {{ISBN|9622099181}}, 9789622099180. p. [https://books.google.com.hk/books?id=LTr9AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA287 287].</ref>
The head office was previously at the Swire House (now the [[Chater House]]) in [[Central, Hong Kong|Central]],<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/19980206010101/http://www.hkis.org.hk/ Home page]. Hong Kong Institute of Surveyors. February 6, 1998. "1934 Swire House, Chater Road, Central, HONG KONG."</ref> but it later moved to the [[Jardine House]] in Central in 1998.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/19980703214156/http://www.hkis.org.hk/ Home page]. Hong Kong Institute of Surveyors. July 3, 1998. "Suite 510, Jardine House, 1 Connaught Place, Central, Hong Kong."</ref>
In 2014 the HKIS stated that the Hong Kong government ought to establish an authority that oversees renovations of older buildings to prevent corruption and wrongful conduct.<ref>Liu, Yvonne. "[http://www.scmp.com/property/hong-kong-china/article/1520046/clean-buildings-renovation-sector-hong-kong-institute Clean up buildings renovation sector, Hong Kong Institute of Surveyors says]" ([https://www.webcitation.org/6j3NCptlk?url=http://www.scmp.com/property/hong-kong-china/article/1520046/clean-buildings-renovation-sector-hong-kong-institute Archive]). ''[[South China Morning Post]]''. Wednesday 28 May 2014. Retrieved on 17 July 2016. Print title: "Stop rot in repairs trade, say surveyors"</ref>
A member of either the HKIS or the RCIS may join the other organization after one year of working in Hong Kong.<ref name=Langdonp106/>
== Organisation ==
The General Council governs the Hong Kong Institute of Surveyors and oversees the functions and activities of the Divisions, Young Surveyors Group, Board of Membership, Board of Education, Board of Professional Development, Surveyors Times Editorial Board, Surveying and Built Environment Editorial Board, and the appointed Committees including the Executive Committee and Standing Committees. The General Council and all boards and divisions are operated by volunteers from the profession and are supported by the HKIS Secretariat.
The HKIS has six divisions by reference to respective professional practices; they are:<ref>http://www.hkis.org.hk/en/pdf/org-201506.jpg</ref> *Building Surveying *General Practice *Land Surveying *Quantity Surveying *Planning and Development *Property and Facility Management
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *"[http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/realtime/finance/20160202/54717121 測量師學會：政府要跟市價調整地價]." ''[[Apple Daily]]''. {{zh-hk icon}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.hkis.org.hk/en/}}
[[Category:Professional associations based in Hong Kong]] [[Category:Surveying organizations]]

{{main|ISO 3166-2}}
'''ISO 3166-2:LT''' is the entry for [[Lithuania]] in [[ISO 3166-2]], part of the [[ISO 3166]] [[standardization|standard]] published by the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO), which defines [[code]]s for the names of the principal [[country subdivision|subdivision]]s (e.g., [[province]]s or [[state (administrative division)|state]]s) of all [[country|countries]] coded in [[ISO 3166-1]].
Currently for Lithuania, ISO 3166-2 codes are defined for [[Counties of Lithuania|10 counties]], [[Municipalities of Lithuania|7 city municipalities, 44 district municipalities, and 9 municipalities]].
Each code consists of two parts, separated by a hyphen. The first part is {{mono|LT}}, the [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2]] code of Lithuania. The second part is two letters.
==Current codes== Subdivision names are listed as in the ISO 3166-2 standard published by the ISO 3166 Maintenance Agency (ISO 3166/MA).
===Counties=== ''Click on the button in the header to sort each column.''

'''Abu'l-Qasim Ubaydallah ibn Abdallah ibn Khordadbeh''' ({{lang-fa|ابوالقاسم عبیدالله ابن خردادبه}}) (c. 820 – 912 [[Common Era|CE]]), better known as '''Ibn Khordadbeh''' or '''Ibn Khurradadhbih''',<ref>[[Charles Verlinden]] uses "Ibn Khordadbeh" in his article ''Les Radaniya et Verdun: à propos de la traite des esclaves slaves vers l'Espagne Musulmane aux IX<sup>è</sup> et X<sup>è</sup> siècles'' (1983), whereas Michael McCormick uses "Ibn Khurradadhbih" in his ''Origins of the European Economy: Communication and Commerce A.D. 300–900'' (2001)</ref> was the author of the earliest surviving Arabic book of administrative geography.<ref name=ei-khordadbeh>{{cite encyclopedia |last=Bosworth |first=C. Edmund | title=EBN KORDADBEH | encyclopedia=[[Encyclopædia Iranica]] | accessdate=2008-02-07|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/ebn-kordadbeh}}</ref> He was a Persian [[geographer]] and bureaucrat of the 9th century. He was the son of [[Abdallah ibn Khordadbeh]], a prominent Abbasid general, who was the son of a [[Zoroastrian]] convert to [[Islam]]. Ibn Khordadbeh was appointed "Director of Posts and Intelligence" for the province of [[Jibal]] in northwestern Iran under the [[Abbasid]] Caliph [[Al-Mu'tamid|al-Mutammid]] (ruled 869–885 CE). In this capacity ibn Khordadbeh served as both postmaster general and the [[Caliph]]'s personal spymaster in that vital province.
Around 846-847CE ibn Khordadbeh wrote ''[[Book of Roads and Kingdoms (ibn Khordadbeh)|Kitāb al Masālik w’al Mamālik]]'' (''The Book of Roads and Kingdoms'') (with the second edition of the book being published in 885CE).<ref>{{citation|last=Hee-Soo|first=Lee|work=Early Korea-Arabic Maritime Relations Based on Muslim Sources|publisher=Korea Journal 31(2) (1991), p26}}</ref> In this work, ibn Khordadbeh described the various peoples and provinces of the [[Abbasid|Abbasid Caliphate]]. Along with maps, the book also includes descriptions of the land, people and culture of the Southern [[Asia]]n coast as far as Brahamputra, The [[Andaman Islands]], [[peninsular Malaysia]] and [[Java (island)|Java]].<ref name=Coedes>{{cite book|last= Coedès|first= George|authorlink= George Coedès|editor= Walter F. Vella|others= trans.Susan Brown Cowing|title= The Indianized States of Southeast Asia|year= 1968|publisher= University of Hawaii Press|isbn= 978-0-8248-0368-1}}</ref>{{rp|108}} The lands of [[Tang Dynasty|Tang China]], [[Unified Silla]] (Korea) and [[Japan]] are referenced within his work.<ref name="Bird2014">{{cite book|author=Isabella Bird|title=Korea and Her Neighbours.: A Narrative of Travel, with an Account of the Recent Vicissitudes and Present Position of the Country. With a Preface by Sir Walter C. Hillier.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hHeKAgAAQBAJ|date=9 January 2014|publisher=Adegi Graphics LLC|isbn=978-0-543-01434-4|chapter=1}}</ref>
Ibn Khordadbeh clearly mentions [[Wāḳwāḳ|Waqwaq]] twice: ''East of China are the lands of Waqwaq, which are so rich in gold that the inhabitants make the chains for their dogs and the collars for their monkeys of this metal. They manufacture tunics woven with gold. Excellent ebony wood is found there.'' And again: ''Gold and ebony are exported from Waqwaq.''<ref>http://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/200504/the.seas.of.sindbad.htm</ref>
The book does not reflect a strong influence from Greek earlier works such as Ptolemy's. The work uses heavily Persian administrative terms, gives considerable weight to Pre-Islamic Iranian history, uses native Iranian cosmological division system of the world. These reflect the existence of Iranian sources at the heart of the work.<ref name=mic>{{cite book|title=Medieval Islamic Civilization: An Encyclopedia|first1=Josef W.|last1=Meri|first2=Jere|last2=Bacharach|publisher=Routledge|year=2005|isbn=0-415-96690-6}} pp. 359–60.</ref>
It is one of the few surviving sources that describes [[Jewish]] merchants known as [[Radhanites]].
Khordadbeh wrote other books. He wrote around 8–9 other books on many subjects such as "descriptive geography" (the book ''Kitāb al Masālik w’al Mamālik''), "etiquettes of listening to music", "Persian genealogy", cooking", "drinking", "astral patterns", "boon-companions", "world history", "music and musical instruments". The book on music had the title ''Kitāb al-lahw wa-l-malahi'' which is on musical matters of Pre-Islamic Persia.<ref name=ei-khordadbeh/><ref name=mic/>
==See also== *[[List of Iranian scholars]]
== References == <references />
==Sources== *{{cite book|author=Ibn Khordadbeh |authorlink=Ibn_Khordadbeh |title=Des routes et des Provinces |url=https://archive.org/details/journalasiatique566sociuoft |volume= |others=Translator: [[Charles Barbier de Meynard]] |year=1865|publisher=[[Journal Asiatique]] |location=Paris |language=French}} * Adler, Elkan. ''Jewish Travellers in the Middle Ages''. New York: Dover Publications, 1987. * Bendiner, Elmer. ''The Rise and Fall of Paradise''. New York: Putnam Books, 1983. * Bareket, Elinoar. "Rādhānites". in ''Jewish Civilization: An Encyclopedia''. Norman Roth, ed. Routledge, 2002. pp 558–561. * Fossier, Robert, ed. ''The Cambridge Illustrated History of the Middle Ages'', vol. 1: 350–950. Cambridge University Press, 1997. * Gil, Moshe. "The Radhanite Merchants and the Land of Radhan." in ''Journal of the Economic and Social History of the Orient'' 17:3 (1976). 299–328. * Israeli, Raphael. "Medieval Muslim Travelers to China" in ''Journal of Muslim Minority Affairs'', 2000
==External links== * {{cite encyclopedia | last = Ahmad | first = S. Maqbul | title=Ibn Khurradādhbih (or Ibn Khurdādhbih), Abu’l-Qāsim ‘Ubayd Allāh ‘Abd Allāh | url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G2-2830902298.html | encyclopedia = [[Dictionary of Scientific Biography|Complete Dictionary of Scientific Biography]] | publisher = Encyclopedia.com | origyear=1970–80 | year = 2008 }} * [http://muslimheritage.com/topics/default.cfm?ArticleID=216 A Review of Muslim Geography]

{{EngvarB|date=July 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Johann Weikhard von Valvasor
Janez Vajkard Valvasor |image = File:Janez Vajkard Valvasor.jpg |image_size = 200px |alt = Johann Weikhard von Valvasor in 1689 |caption = Valvasor in 1689 |birth_name = |birth_date = 1641 |birth_place = Laibach, [[Carniola]], (now [[Ljubljana]], [[Slovenia]]) |death_date = September or October 1693 (aged 52) |death_place = [[Krško]], [[Carniola]] |body_discovered = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = [[nobleman]], scholar, [[polymath]] |education = |alma_mater = |employer = |occupation = |years_active = |home_town = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |title = Member of the [[Royal Society]] |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |opponents = |boards = |religion = |spouse = Anna Rosina Valvasor née Grafenweger |partner = |children = |parents = Bartholomäus von Valvasor
Anna Maria von Valvasor née Rauber |relations = |callsign = |awards = |signature = |website = http://www.valvasor.org |footnotes = }} [[File:Izvirnik Slave vojvodine Kranjske iz leta 1689.jpg|thumb|Valvasor's ''[[The Glory of the Duchy of Carniola]]'', published 1689]] [[File:Topographia Archiducatus Carinthiae antiquae et modernae completa (title page).jpg|thumb|Title page of his ''Topographia Archiducatus Carinthiae antiquae et modernae completa'', 1688]] [[File:Hrvaška-Valvasor.jpg|thumb|Valvasor's map of [[Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)|Croatia]] (1689)]] '''Johann Weikhard Freiherr von Valvasor'''{{#tag:ref|The word "Freiherr" denotes a [[baron]]. Valvasor never officially held the title, but was referred to as such by the people who admired him and gradually adopted it also himself in his writings.{{cite journal |url=http://www.zgodovinskicasopis.si/_pdf/Digital-archive/ZC_2007_3-4.pdf |first=Boris |last=Golec |title=Neznano in presenetljivo o življenju, družini, smrti, grobu in zapuščini Janeza Vajkarda Valvasorja |language=Slovenian, English, German|trans-title=Hitherto Unknown and Surprising Findings about the Life, Family, Death, Gravesite, and Legacy of Janez Vajkard Valvasor |journal=Zgodovinski časopis [Historical review]: glasilo Zveze zgodovinskih društev Slovenije |volume=61 |year=2007 |issue=3–4 |issn=0350-5774 |id={{COBISS|ID=27721261}} |pages=303–364}} |group=Note}} or '''Johann Weichard Freiherr von Valvasor'''{{#tag:ref|Although the spelling ''Weichard'' is used in ''Die Ehre...'' and ''Topographia...'', the spelling ''Weikhard'' is more common in printed sources today.|group=Note}} ({{lang-sl|Janez Vajkard Valvasor}}, {{IPA-sl|ˈʋáːlʋazɔɾ|pron}}){{cite web|title=Slovenski pravopis 2001|url=http://bos.zrc-sazu.si/c/SP/neva.exe?name=sp&expression=Valvasor&hs=1|accessdate=25 March 2015}} or simply '''Valvasor''' (baptised on 28 May 1641 – September or October 1693) was a [[natural historian]] and [[polymath]] from [[Carniola]], present-day [[Slovenia]], and a [[List of Fellows of the Royal Society elected in 1687|fellow]] of the [[Royal Society]] in London. He is known as a pioneer of study of [[karst topography|karst studies]]. Together with his other writings, until the late 19th century his best-known work—the 1689 ''[[The Glory of the Duchy of Carniola|Glory of the Duchy of Carniola]]'', published in 15 books in four volumes—was the main source for older [[History of Slovenia|Slovenian history]], making him one of the precursors of modern Slovenian historiography.Reisp, Branko et al. (1987): ''Korespondenca Janeza Vajkarda Valvasorja z Royal Society''. Ljubljana: SAZU, p. 15. ==Biography== Valvasor was born in the town of [[Ljubljana]], then [[Duchy of Carniola]], now the capital of Slovenia. In the 16th century, It was Johann Baptist Valvasor who established the family Valvasor in the Duchy of Carniola in central Europe in a part of Austria that is now the Republic of Slovenia. In medieval Latin "[[Vavasour|Valvasor]]" or "Valvasore" held the meaning "the carrier of the feud". In western Europe its use can be traced back to the 11th century. Neither the exact day nor the actual place of Valvasor's birth are known, but his baptism was registered at [[Ljubljana Cathedral]]. He was the twelfth child born to Bartholomäus and Anna Maria Freiin von Rauber, who did not only live at their [[Medija Castle]] in [[Izlake]] but also had a town residence in Ljubljana at [[Old Square (Ljubljana)|Old Square]]. His godparents were Freiherr (Baron) Konrad Ruess von Ruessenstein from the [[Strmol Castle]] and Regina Dorothea Rasp from the [[Krumperk Castle]]. Valvasor's father died when the boy was ten years old. His mother died when he was 16. At the time he was attending the [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit]] school in Ljubljana.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KvMTCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA215 |chapter=Janez Vajkard / Johann Weikhard Valvasor |page=215 |title=Slovenski književniki v Ljubljani |trans-title=Slovene Literates in Ljubljana |language=Slovenian|publisher=ZRC |first=Marjan |last=Dolgan |first2=Jerneja |last2=Fridl |first3=Manca |last3=Volk |year=2014 |isbn=9789612547110}} Graduating in 1659 at the age of seventeen, he did not choose to continue his studies at a university but decided to broaden his horizons by meeting learned men on a journey across Europe. This journey lasted fourteen years and it even took him to northern Africa. During this period, he joined the army in the [[Austrian-Turkish War]], where he became closely acquainted with the conditions on the [[Croatian Military Frontier]]. Shortly after marrying Anna Rosina Grafenweger in 1672, Valvasor acquired the [[Bogenšperk Castle]] near [[Litija]], where he arranged a writing, drawing and printing workshop. Valvasor spent a fortune on the publishing of his books; towards the end of his life, his debts forced him to sell Bogenšperk Castle, his vast library and his collection of prints. In 1690, Aleksandar Ignacije Mikulić, the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Zagreb|Bishop of Zagreb]], bought his library, along with some 7,300 graphics, and moved it to Slavonia, where the collection became part of the library of the Zagreb Archbishopric, now part of the [[Croatian State Archives]].[http://www.arhiv.hr/hr/hda/fs-ovi/metropolitana.htm Croatian State Archives], Division of the Zagreb Archbishopy. Retrieved 3 April 2009 {{hr icon}} {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081019040253/http://www.arhiv.hr/hr/hda/fs-ovi/metropolitana.htm |date=19 October 2008 }} Valvasor died in September 1693 in [[Krško]]. He is believed to have been buried in the family crypt at [[Medija Castle]],{{cite web|title=Valvasor, Janez Vajkard, baron|url=http://www.slovenska-biografija.si/oseba/sbi759993/|website=Slovenski biografski leksikon|accessdate=April 15, 2018}} but this is uncertain. The [[Yugoslav Partisans]] dynamited the castle in 1944Information sign posted at Medija Castle. and no trace of his putative grave remains today. ==Legacy== ===The Glory of the Duchy of Carniola=== Valvasor's most important work remains ''[[The Glory of the Duchy of Carniola]]'' (original title: {{lang|de|Die Ehre deß Herzogthums Crain}},Johann Weichard von Valvasor: {{lang|de|Die Ehre Deß Hertzogthums Crain, Das ist, Wahre, gründliche, und recht eigendliche Gelegen- und Beschaffenheit dieses, in manchen alten und neuen Geschicht-Büchern zwar rühmlich berührten, doch bishero nie annoch recht beschriebenen Römisch-Keyserlichen herrlichen Erblandes : Anjetzo, Vermittelst einer vollkommenen und ausführlichen Erzehlung aller seiner Landschafften, Felder ... alter und neuer Denckwürdigkeiten ... Jn Funffzehen, wiewol in vier Haupt-Theile unterschiedenen, Büchern, wie auch häuffigen Abrissen und zierlichen Kupffer-Figuren, ausgebreitet / von Johann Weichard Valvasor, Freyherrn. Aber Jn reines Teutsch gebracht von Erasmum Francisci. Laybach}}, {{lang|la|Anno MDCLXXXIX.}}''{{Cite magazine |last=Ley |first=Willy |author= |last2= |first2= |last3= |first3= |date=February 1968 |title=Epitaph for a Lonely Olm |department=For Your Information |url=https://archive.org/stream/Galaxy_v26n03_1968-02_modified#page/n37/mode/2up |magazine=Galaxy Science Fiction |pages=95-104 |type= }} Slovene: {{lang|sl|Slava vojvodine Kranjske}}), published in 1689{{Cite book|url=http://atena.beic.it/webclient/DeliveryManager?pid=13398218&search_terms=DTL173|title=Die Ehre dess Hertzogthums Crain|last=|first=|work=Acta Eruditorum|publisher=|year=1689|isbn=|location=Leipzig|pages=549 [i.e. 529]}} in 15 tomes, totalling 3532 pages and including 528 illustrations and 24 appendices, which provides a vivid description of Carniola at the time. He also recorded the first written document on [[vampire]]s when he wrote on the legend of a vampire in [[Istria]] named [[Jure Grando]].Boris Perić, ''[http://www.naklada-ljevak.hr/knjiga/show/id/187 Vampir]'', Biblioteka 21, Zagreb ( Naklada Ljevak) 2006. (Croat) {{ISBN|953-178-741-7}}Boris Perić, ''Vampir'', translated into Slovene by Iztok Osojnik, Zbirka Beri globalno, Ljubljana (Tuma) 2007. {{ISBN|978-961-6682-05-3}} From 2009 until 2012, it was translated into Slovene by [[Doris Debenjak|Doris]], [[Primož Debenjak|Primož]] and [[Božidar Debenjak]]. The initiator, project manager, editor and technical editor of this monumental publishing project was [[Tomaž Čeč]].{{cite web |url=http://www.rtvslo.si/kultura/knjige/veliki-podvig-prevajanja-valvasorja-je-zakljucen/284697 |title=Veliki podvig prevajanja Valvasorja je zaključen |work=MMC RTV Slovenija |date=6 June 2012 |publisher=RTV Slovenija}} ===Karst research=== Valvasor was a pioneer of study of [[karst topography|karst phenomena]]. Upon the proposal of [[Edmond Halley]], who was not only an astronomer but also a geophysicist, and in 1687 his extensive treatise on the [[hydrology]] of the intermittent [[Lake Cerknica]] won him a Fellowship of the Royal Society.Reisp, Branko et al. 1987. ''Korespondenca Janeza Vajkarda Valvasorja z Royal Society''. Ljubljana: SAZU, p. 15. == Works == *''Dominicae passionis icones'', 1679, reprint 1970 {{COBISS|ID=261635}} *''Topographia Ducatus Carnioliae modernae'' das ist Controfee aller Stätt, Märckht, Clöster und Schlösser, wie sie anietzo stehen in dem Herzogthumb Crain, 1679, reprint 1970 {{COBISS|ID=19019831}} *''Topographia arcium Lambergianarum'' id est arces, castella et dominia in Carniolia habita possident comites a Lamberg; Bagenspergi (Bogenšperg), 1679 {{COBISS|ID=75121664}}, reprint 1995 {{COBISS|ID=50098688}} * ''Topographia Archiducatus Carinthiae modernae'': das ist Controfee aller Stätt, Märckht, Clöster, undt Schlösser, wie sie anietzo stehen in dem Ertzhertzogthumb Khärnten; Wagensperg in Crain (Bogenšperg), 1681 {{COBISS|ID=87695872}}; Nürnberg, 1688 {{COBISS|ID=87695872}} *''Carniolia, Karstia, Histria et Windorum Marchia'', Labaci (Ljubljana) 1681 {{COBISS|ID=217886464}} *''Theatrum mortis humanae tripartitum'': figuris aeneis illustratum : das ist: Schau-Bühne des menschlichen Todts in drey Theil : mit schönen Kupffer-Stichen geziehrt vnd an Tag gegeben; Laybach, Saltzburg (Ljubljana, Salzburg); 1682 {{COBISS|ID=53622528}} *''Topographia Archiducatus Carinthiae antiquae & modernae completa'': Das ist Vollkommene und gründliche Land – Beschreibung des berühmten Erz – Herzogthums Kärndten; Nürnberg 1688, {{COBISS|ID=87695872}} *''Opus insignium armorumque'' ... ;(1687–1688) {{COBISS|ID=33650176}} *[[File:Acta Eruditorum - XIII slovenia geografia, 1689 – BEIC 13398218.jpg|thumb|Illustration from critique of first volume of ''Die Ehre deß Hertzogthums Crain'' published in ''[[Acta Eruditorum]]'', 1689]]''[[The Glory of the Duchy of Carniola|Die Ehre deß Hertzogthums Crain]]'':'' das ist, Wahre, gründliche, und recht eigendliche Belegen- und Beschaffenheit dieses Römisch-Keyserlichen herrlichen Erblandes''; Laybach (Ljubljana) 1689 {{COBISS|ID=29952257}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=Note}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Commons category|Johann Weikhard von Valvasor}} *[http://www.valvasor.org/index.php Valvasor.org – Life and work of Johann Weichard Freiherr von Valvasor]{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *[https://www.scribd.com/people/documents/27348484-johann-weikhard-freiherr-von-valvasor J.W.F. Valvasor Digital Library on scribd.com] {{-}} {{Krško |state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Valvasor, Janez Vajkard}} [[Category:1641 births]] [[Category:1693 deaths]] [[Category:Carniolan historians]] [[Category:Carniolan geographers]] [[Category:Carniolan ethnographers]] [[Category:Carniolan topographers]] [[Category:Carniolan cartographers]] [[Category:Carniolan alchemists]] [[Category:Carniolan publishers (people)]] [[Category:Carniolan soldiers]] [[Category:Carniolan inventors]] [[Category:Carniolan collectors]] [[Category:Carniolan nobility]] [[Category:Carniolan writers]] [[Category:German-language writers]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Karstologists]] [[Category:17th-century cartographers]]

{{wikt}} '''Kolk''' may refer to:
==People== * [[Ryan Kolk, PGA]] (born 1981), American Professional Golfer * [[Douglas Kolk]] (1963–2014), American artist * [[Hanco Kolk]] (born 1957), Dutch cartoonist * [[Santi Kolk]] (born 1981), Dutch footballer * [[Scott Kolk]] (1905–1993), American actor * [[Oets Kolk Bouwsma]] (1898–1978), American philosopher
==Other== * [[KOLK]], a radio station licensed to Lakeside, Montana, United States * [[Kolk (bog)]], a waterbody in the middle of a raised or kettle bog * [[Kolk (vortex)]], a powerful underwater vortex * [[Kolk, Zagorje ob Savi]], a settlement in Upper Carniola, Slovenia * [[Kolk (Heidmark)]], a village destroyed to make the [[Bergen-Hohne Training Area]] in Lower Saxony, Germany * [[Kolk-Spandau]], a subdivision of [[Spandau (locality)|Spandau]] in Spandau Borough, Berlin, Germany
==See also== * [[Van der Kolk]], a surname (including a list of people with the name)

{{Infobox highway system |title=National Trunk Highway System |markers=[[File:China Expwy GXX sign no name.svg|150px]] |caption=NTHS expressway marker |map=China National Expressway Network.svg |map_alt= |map_notes=NTHS expressway in China |maint= |formed= 13 January 2005 |length_mi= |length_ref= |label1=NTHS: |field1=GXX (green) |notes= |country=CHN |type=G }} '''Primary NTHS Expressways''' of [[China]] are numbered with one- or two-digit designations; the 9X series routes are zonal beltways. Generally, one-digit routes radiate from Beijing, odd-numbered routes run north-south, with lower numbers in the east and higher numbers in the west; even-numbered routes run east-west, with lower numbers in the north and higher numbers in the south. Their [[List of auxiliary NTHS Expressways|associated branch expressways]] are follow by a cardinal points (N, S, E, W) and additional digit if repeated starting with 2; for associated auxiliary expressways are follow by two additional digits. {{TOClimit|3}} {{clear}} ==Primary NTHS Expressways== {| class="wikitable sortable" !Number||Name||Chinese Name||Origin||Terminus||Length||Formed||Notes |- |bgcolor="lightgrey"|{{jct|country=CHN|Ex|1}}||Jingha Expressway||{{lang|zh-hans|京哈高速}}||[[Beijing|Beijing, BJ]]||[[Harbin|Harbin, HL]]||{{convert|1,205|km|mi|abbr=on}}||2005|| |- |bgcolor="lightgrey"|{{jct|country=CHN|Ex|2}}||Jinghu Expressway||{{lang|zh-hans|京沪高速}}||[[Beijing|Beijing, BJ]]||[[Shanghai|Shanghai, SH]]||{{convert|1,220|km|mi|abbr=on}}||2006|| |- |bgcolor="lightgrey"|{{jct|country=CHN|Ex|3}}||Jingtai Expressway||{{lang|zh-hans|京台高速}}||[[Beijing|Beijing, BJ]]||[[Fuzhou|Fuzhou, FJ]] {{small|(''[[Taipei|Taipei, TW]]'')}}||{{convert|1,872|km|mi|abbr=on}}||||{{small|See also [[Political Status of Taiwan]]. revision.text:
{{Prose|date=April 2015}} This is a list of [[flag]]s which are entirely or largely [[black (color)|black]].
==In history== <!--Dated references here, in order--> [[File:Flag of Afghanistan (1880–1901).svg|thumb|Solid black flag; flag of the [[Emirate of Afghanistan]] from 1880-1901.]] [[File:Flag_of_the_National_Fascist_Party_(PNF).svg|thumb|Flag of the [[Fascist National Party]] (Partito Nazionale Fascista) from 1926 to 1943. There were variations of the flag with different styles of fasces, this image shows one of those styles.]] * A black flag ([[Black Standard]]) was used by [[Muhammad]] to represent his religion.<ref>[http://www.fotw.net/flags/islam.html ''Islamic Flags''] at Flags of the World</ref> It was used as the standard of the Abbasid Caliphate. It has also been stated that it will be the flag of the army that will fight the ''[[Dajjal]]''. * During the [[German Peasants' War]] in the 16th century the black flag was used by the revolting farmers. *[[Afghanistan]] flew a solid black flag from 1709–38 and from 1880–1901 (see [[Flag of Afghanistan]]). * The black flag with the motto ''Viurem lliures o morirem'' (We live free or die) was flown by Catalan army and militia corps during the final stages of the [[War of the Spanish Succession]], when the Allies had already abandoned Catalonia that fought alone against the Spanish and French armies during 1713-1714. This black flag was packaged in 2012 with the historical novel [http://www.lliuresomorts.cat ''Lliures o Morts''] (Live Free or Die) authored by Jaume Clotet and David de Montserrat. * The Black Flag was flown by certain irregular [[Confederate Army]] units in the [[American Civil War]] of 1861-1865 to symbolize that they would neither give, nor accept [[No quarter|quarter]]; symbolizing the opposite of the [[white flag]] of [[Surrender (military)|surrender]]. * The [[Anarchist symbolism#Black flag|Anarchist black flag]] has been an anarchist symbol since the 1880s. Anarchists use either a plain black flag or a black flag with an "A" and an "O" around it, this symbol is a reference to a [[Proudhon]] quote "'''A'''narchy is '''O'''rder Without Power".<ref>Marshall, Peter. [[Demanding the Impossible]]. Fontana, London. 1993. p. 558</ref> * The color black was famous as the flag of [[Kingdom of Italy|Italy]]'s [[National Fascist Party]], designed after the party's paramilitary [[Milizia Volontaria per la Sicurezza Nazionale|Blackshirts]]. * Upon the surrender of Nazi Germany in [[World War II]] German [[U-boat]]s were ordered to fly a black flag and sail to an [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] port and surrender.<ref>{{cite web|title=SPECIAL ORDERS BY THE SUPREME COMMANDER, ALLIED EXPEDITIONARY FORCE TO THE GERMAN HIGH COMMAND RELATING TO NAVAL FORCES|url=http://avalon.law.yale.edu/wwii/gs5.asp|accessdate=2013-11-23}}</ref> [[File:Flag_of_Edward_England.svg|thumb|The traditional "[[Jolly Roger]]" of [[piracy]].]] [[File:Liwa-e-Ahmadiyya 1-2.svg|thumb|Flag of the [[Ahmadiyya]] Muslim Community, first designed in the 1930s. For Ahmadi Muslims, it symbolizes the advent of the [[Mahdi]].]] [[File:Chetniks_Flag.svg|thumb|[[Chetniks|Chetnik]] flag inscription reads: "For king and fatherland; freedom or death".]] * The [[Jolly Roger]], or '''skull and crossbones''', is flown to identify a ship's crew as pirates about to attack. The flag most commonly identified as the Jolly Roger today is the skull and crossbones (although swords are also common), a flag consisting of a human skull above two long bones (probably tibias) set in an x-mark arrangement, most usually depicted crossing each other directly under the skull, on a black field. This design was used by several pirates, including Captains "Black Sam" Bellamy, Edward England, and John Taylor. Some Jolly Roger flags also include an hourglass, another common symbol representing death in 17th- and 18th-century Europe. Despite the prominence of flags with art in popular culture, plain black flags with no art were often employed by most pirates in the 17th–18th century. Historically, the flag was flown to frighten the pirates' victims into surrendering without a fight, since it conveyed the message that the attackers were outlaws who would not consider themselves bound by the usual rules of engagement—and might, therefore, slaughter those they defeated (since captured pirates were usually hanged, they did not have much to gain by asking quarter if defeated). Since the decline of piracy, various military units have used the Jolly Roger, usually in skull-and-crossbones design, as a unit identification insignia or a victory flag to ascribe to themselves the proverbial ferocity and toughness of pirates. In a non-naval context the skull and crossbones motif has additional meanings, for example, to signify a hazard such as poison * The [[Ahmadiyya]] flag, first designed in the 1930s during the second [[Khalifatul Masih|Caliphate]]. Just as the black colour absorbs visible light, similarly the black colour symbolizes the absorption of spiritual light. * The flag of the [[Chetniks|Chetnik]] movement in [[Serbia]] and former [[Yugoslavia]] during the 20th century, with the words "''Sloboda ili smrt'' ('liberty or death') inscribed in white under a skull.
===Jihadism in the 20th/21st century=== [[File:Flag_of_Jihad.svg|thumb|The "[[black flag of jihad]]" as used by jihadist militants since around the late 1990s.]] In [[Ali Soufan]]'s book ''The Black Banners'', he explains the title by noting that quotes from various [[Hadith]]s regarding "Black Banners" of a "new army" taking over Khorasan have some kind of prophetic significance with many modern adherents of [[Islamic extremism|extremist]] [[jihadism]]. He notes that it is "not a coincidence" that [[Osama bin Laden]] made [[al-Qaeda]]'s flag black. Soufan also notes that there is debate about whether the prophet Mohammed actually spoke some of the quoted Hadiths (such as one attributed to [[Abu Hurairah]]). He also notes that Sheikh [[Salman al-Ouda]] has said the Black Banner hadiths are not able to be authenticated.<ref>The Black Banners, [[Ali Soufan]], 2011, [[W. W. Norton & Company]]</ref>
==In society== [[File:PsPr-lippu.jpg|thumb|right|Flag of the [[Armoured Brigade (Finland)|Armoured Brigade]] of the [[Finnish Army]].]] [[File:United States POW-MIA flag.svg|thumb|Flag of the [[National League of POW/MIA Families]].]] [[File:Rozlouceni s vaclavem havlem vladislavsky sal 443.jpg|thumb|right|Flag of mourning in Prague Castle.]] <!--Non-dated references--> * Black flags are often associated with funerals in the West, particularly state funerals and public [[mourning]]. * In the former [[Yugoslavia]], a plain black flag is the flag of mourning. It is displayed for 40 days after death on the deceased person's house. * The black flag is the symbol of the Jewish ultra-Orthodox, anti-Zionist group, [[Neturei Karta]]. It is flown as a sign of mourning over the creation of the [[State of Israel]], most commonly on [[Israeli Independence Day]]. * The [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[Pirate Party (Sweden)|Pirate Party]] have a black flag as a symbol, shaped like the letter P. * In the German and Finnish militaries, black has been the traditional color of armored troops, which carries over to the flags of armored units. In Finland, also combat engineers have a black flag. The Armoured Brigade has a black flag defaced with a helmet, and engineer battalions have the black flags defaced with various symbols. * The New Zealand Rugby Union team, commonly known as the All Blacks, have a predominantly black flag with a white fern superimposed [[List of New Zealand flags]].
==In competition, as a signal== * The black flag is a [[racing flag]] used to summon a driver to the pits. * In [[Racing Rules of Sailing|sail racing]], when the black flag is displayed with the [[Racing Rules of Sailing#Preparatory signal|preparatory signal]], a boat that is over the starting line in the minute prior to the starting signal is immediately disqualified without a hearing. * In some forms of racing, <!--including most small boat races (especially [[sailing]] races)--> a black flag is used to disqualify competitors or indicate some other penalty (such as a forced pit stop in [[NASCAR]]).
==Fictional black flags== * In ''[[The Silmarillion]]'' and other [[Middle-earth]] writings of [[J.R.R. Tolkien]], the banner of the evil overlord [[Morgoth]] is described as being entirely black with no insignia.
== See also == *[[Red flag (politics)]] *[[Racing flags#Yellow flag|Yellow flag]] *[[Green flag]] *[[Blue flag (disambiguation)]] *[[Bonnie Blue Flag]] *[[White flag]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Lists and galleries of flags|Black flags]] [[Category:Flags by design|Black]] [[Category:Black symbols|Flags, black, list of]]
[[ja:黒旗]]

page.title: List of companies of Puerto Rico

revision.text:
[[File:Puerto Rico (orthographic projection).svg|thumb|Location of [[Puerto Rico]]]]
[[Puerto Rico]] is an [[Unincorporated territories of the United States|unincorporated territory]] of the [[United States]] located in the northeast [[Caribbean Sea]]. It is an [[archipelago]] that includes the main island of Puerto Rico and a number of smaller ones such as [[Isla de Mona|Mona]], [[Culebra, Puerto Rico|Culebra]], and [[Vieques, Puerto Rico|Vieques]]. The [[List of capitals in the United States|capital]] and [[Municipalities of Puerto Rico|most populous city]] is [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]]. Its official languages are [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[English language|English]], though Spanish predominates.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.prfaa.pr.gov/puertoricond2.asp |title=About Puerto Rico |accessdate=September 21, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150912144331/http://prfaa.pr.gov/puertoricond2.asp |archivedate=September 12, 2015 |publisher=Puerto Rico Federal Affairs Administration}}</ref> The island's population is approximately 3.4 million.
== Notable firms == This list includes notable [[company|companies]] with primary [[headquarters]] located in the country. The industry and sector follow the [[Industry Classification Benchmark]] taxonomy. Organizations which have ceased operations are included and noted as defunct. {{Company-list table start}} {{Company-list table entry | [[Air Flamenco]] | Consumer services | Airlines | [[Culebra, revision.text:
[[File:Cismigiu Lake 1.jpg|thumb|Lake Cișmigiu]] [[File:Lacul Floreasca (vedere din Parcul Bordei).JPG|thumb|Lake Floreasca]] [[File:Bucuresti, Romania, Parcul Herastrau (Imagine de pe lacul Herastrau); B-II-a-A-18802 (3).JPG|thumb|Lake Herăstrău]] [[File:Lacul IOR, Bucureşti.jpg|thumb|Lake Titan]]
The '''Lakes, Parks and Leisure Administration in [[Bucharest]]''' ({{lang-ro|Administraţia Lacuri, Parcuri şi Agrement}}) has under its upkeep nine lakes and nine dams, from the total of 15 located on the [[Colentina River]], that started to be built since 1936 and that cover a total area of {{convert|1153.98|ha|km2|abbr=on}} and have a combined volume of {{convert|29571000|m3|ft3|abbr=on}}.<ref name="În ADMINISTRARE">{{cite web|url=http://www.alpa.ro/|title=În ADMINISTRARE|date=2009-02-17|publisher=Administraţia Lacuri, Parcuri şi Agrement|language=Romanian|accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref> The largest lake inside [[Bucharest]], in terms of surface area, is the [[Morii Lake|Lake Morii]],<ref name="ShowLaculMorii">[http://www.ziare.com/weekend/spectacole/miting-aeronautic-pe-lacul-morii-in-weekend-1092545 Show aeronautic pe Lacul Morii], Ziare.com, May 27, 2011</ref> other large lakes with banks in Bucharest or parts in Bucharest are the [[Lake Cernica]] that has an area of {{convert|341|ha|km2|abbr=on}}; and the largest in terms of volume is [[Lake Pantelimon]] with a volume of {{convert|12300000|m3|ft3|abbr=on}}.<ref name="În ADMINISTRARE"/> The oldest manmade lake in Bucharest is the Herăstrău Lake completed in 1936 that also has the oldest [[sluice]] in the city built between 1933 and 1936 that was finalised in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediafax.ro/social/ecluza-herastrau-deschisa.html?1688;906002|title=Ecluza Herăstrău a fost deschisă|date=2007-09-07|publisher=Mediafax|language=Romanian|accessdate=2009-02-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://stiri.rol.ro/content/view/78679/2/|title=Prima ecluza din Bucuresti|date=2007-09-08|publisher=StiriRol.ro|language=Romanian|accessdate=2009-02-18}}</ref>
==List of lakes==
'''[[Lake Băneasa]]''' is located in [[Sector 1 (Bucharest)|Sectorul 1]], it has a length of {{convert|3|km|mi|abbr=on}}, a width between {{convert|50|m|ft|abbr=on}} and {{convert|400|m|ft|abbr=on}}, a surface area of {{convert|40|ha|km2|abbr=on}}, a depth between {{convert|1|m|ft|abbr=on}} and {{convert|3|m|ft|abbr=on}}, a volume of {{convert|630000|m3|ft3|abbr=on}} and a debit of 2.5 m/s.<ref name="În ADMINISTRARE"/>
'''[[Lake Cișmigiu]]''' is located in [[Sector 1 (Bucharest)|Sectorul 1]], it has a length of {{convert|1.3|km|mi|abbr=on}}, a width of {{convert|50|m|ft|abbr=on}}, a surface area of {{convert|2.65|ha|ft2|abbr=on}}, a depth between {{convert|1|m|ft|abbr=on}} and {{convert|2|m|ft|abbr=on}}, and a volume of {{convert|290000|m3|ft3|abbr=on}}.<ref name="În ADMINISTRARE"/>
'''[[Lake Dâmbovița]]''' is located in [[Sector 6 (Bucharest)|Sectorul 6]] and coveres a surface of {{convert|55|ha|km2|abbr=on}}.<ref name="În ADMINISTRARE"/>
'''[[Lake Fundeni]]''' is located in [[Sector 2 (Bucharest)|Sectorul 2]]
'''[[Lake Floreasca]]''' is located in [[Sector 1 (Bucharest)|Sectorul 1]], it has a length of {{convert|3|km|mi|abbr=on}}, a width between {{convert|100|m|ft|abbr=on}} and {{convert|800|m|ft|abbr=on}}, a surface area of {{convert|70|ha|km2|abbr=on}}, a depth between {{convert|1|m|ft|abbr=on}} and {{convert|5|m|ft|abbr=on}}, a volume of {{convert|1600000|m3|ft3|abbr=on}} and a debit of 2.5 m/s.<ref name="În ADMINISTRARE"/>
'''Lake Grivița''' is located in [[Sector 1 (Bucharest)|Sectorul 1]], it has a length of {{convert|3.8|km|mi|abbr=on}}, a width between {{convert|50|m|ft|abbr=on}} and {{convert|500|m|ft|abbr=on}}, a surface area of {{convert|53|ha|km2|abbr=on}}, a depth between {{convert|1|m|ft|abbr=on}} and {{convert|4|m|ft|abbr=on}}, a volume of {{convert|1000000|m3|ft3|abbr=on}} and a debit of 2.5 m/s.<ref name="În ADMINISTRARE"/>
'''[[Lake Herăstrău]]''' is located in [[Sector 1 (Bucharest)|Sectorul 1]] and coveres a surface of {{convert|74|ha|km2|abbr=on}}.<ref name="În ADMINISTRARE"/>
'''[[Lacul Lebedelor]]''' is a small lake located close to [[Lake Cișmigiu]] in [[Sector 1 (Bucharest)|Sectorul 1]] and reserved for water birds.
'''[[Lacul Morii]]''' ("Mill Lake") is the largest lake in [[Bucharest]],<ref name="ShowLaculMorii"/> located in [[Sector 6 (Bucharest)|Sectorul 6]], it has a length of {{convert|7|km|mi|abbr=on}}, a surface area of {{convert|246|ha|km2|abbr=on}}, a depth between of {{convert|6|m|ft|abbr=on}} and a volume of {{convert|14700000|m3|ft3|abbr=on}}.<ref name="În ADMINISTRARE"/>
'''Lake Pantelimon''' is located in [[Sector 2 (Bucharest)|Sectorul 2]] and covers a surface of {{convert|260|ha|km2|abbr=on}}, but most of the lake is outside Bucharest, in [[Pantelimon, Bucharest|Pantelimon]].<ref name="În ADMINISTRARE"/>
'''Lake Plumbuita''' is located in [[Sector 2 (Bucharest)|Sectorul 2]].
'''Lake Străulești''' is located in [[Sector 1 (Bucharest)|Sectorul 1]], it has a length of {{convert|2.3|km|mi|abbr=on}}, a width between {{convert|100|m|ft|abbr=on}} and {{convert|300|m|ft|abbr=on}}, a surface area of {{convert|33|ha|km2|abbr=on}}, a depth between {{convert|1|m|ft|abbr=on}} and {{convert|5|m|ft|abbr=on}}, and a volume of {{convert|700000|m3|ft3|abbr=on}}.<ref name="În ADMINISTRARE"/>
'''[[Lake Tineretului]]''' is located in [[Tineretului Park]].
'''[[Lake Tei]] is in [[Tei Park]].
'''[[Lake Titan]] is in [[Titan Park]].
'''Lake Văcărești''' is located in [[Sector 4 (Bucharest)|Sectorul 4]] and coveres a surface of {{convert|189|ha|km2|abbr=on}}.<ref name="În ADMINISTRARE"/>
Other lakes include Dobroești, the lake from Drumul Taberei Park, the lake from Carol Park.<ref name="În ADMINISTRARE"/>

{{For|the lake in Norway|Langsjøen}} {{Infobox lake | name = Långsjön | image = Långsjön Segeltorp 2015.jpg | caption = View looking east | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | coords = {{coord|59|16|3|N|17|57|59|E|region:SE_type:waterbody_scale:100000|display=inline,title}} | type = | inflow = | outflow = [[Mälaren|Lake Mälaren]] | catchment = {{convert|243|ha|abbr=on}} | basin_countries = Sweden | length = | width = | area = {{convert|29|ha|abbr=on}} | depth = {{convert|2.2|m|abbr=on}} | max-depth = {{convert|3.3|m|abbr=on}} | volume = {{convert|617,000|m3|acre.ft|abbr=on}} | residence_time = 9-10 months | shore = {{convert|4,940|m|abbr=on}} (including islands) | elevation = {{convert|30.6|m|abbr=on}} | islands = Three ({{convert|0.17|ha|acre|disp=or}}) | cities = [[Huddinge]], [[Stockholm]] | reference = <ref name="vattenprogram-15.1">Vattenprogram, p 15.1</ref><ref name="vattenprogram-15.10">Vattenprogram, p 15.10</ref> }} '''Långsjön''' ({{lang-en|The Long Lake}}) is a [[lake]] in southern [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]]. The lake is situated in an old residential neighbourhood located between the municipalities of [[Stockholm]] and [[Huddinge]] and most of the shoreline is private property. Water level is controlled by a [[sluice]] in the north-western end of the lake where the lake empties into Lake [[Mälaren]] through a system of dikes and culverts. Polluted waste water was poured directly into the lake during the early 20th century which caused up to two third of the lake to be choked-up until the 1940s. It was subsequently one of the first lakes in Stockholm to be subject for various attempts to restorations.<ref name="vattenprogram-15.1" /> The northern shores are waterlogged whilst the bedrock surfaces along the southern. The lake has no major feeders, the inflow instead coming from local [[stormwater]] and [[surface runoff]].<ref name="vattenprogram-15.3">Vattenprogram, p 15.3-15.4</ref>
== Catchment area == Some 60 per cent of the lake catchment area is occupied by settlements, mostly one-family houses but several minor green spaces are scattered around the lake. South-wester of the lake is a small area forming part of the [[Gömmaren]] nature reserve. The lake has two bathes.<ref name="vattenprogram-15.3" />
=== Environmental influence === The number of polluting operations in the catchment area is limited to a petrol station and an engineering workshop. In the end of the 1930s sewers were built in the area and the waste water fed into the lake during the 1920s and 1930s is today brought to the wastewater treatment works at [[Henriksdal]], but old sewers still leak into the lake and the water was considered unfit for bathing at several occasions during the 1990s. Långsjön is one of few lakes in Stockholm where spillway overflow adds appreciable amounts of [[phosphorus]]. [[Surface runoff]] adds some 70 kg of phosphorus and 1,000 kg of nitrogen annually and more than half of phosphorus added through surface water is produced by the surrounding one-family houses and their gardens. <ref name="vattenprogram-15.3" />
== Flora and fauna == In August, the stock of [[phytoplankton]] is dominated by [[cyanobacteria]] and [[green algae]], of which several are potentially poisonous and caused major [[algae bloom]]s during the 1990s. The community of [[zooplankton]] is representative for lakes rich in nutrients with medium-sized [[taxon|taxa]] dominating in late spring and June, while minor taxa are otherwise prevailing. Larger zooplankton, such as [[Cyclopoida|Cyclopoid]] [[Copepod]]s, are rare and reaches about 40 per cent in July and August.<ref name="vattenprogram-15.5">Vattenprogram, p 15.5-15.7</ref>
No inventory of [[aquatic plant]]s has been done since the mid-1970s, but [[Nymphaea alba|white waterlily]] is common in the minor bays. [[Nuphar lutea|yellow water-lily]] occur in minor numbers but [[reed bed]]s are missing.<ref name="vattenprogram-15.5" />
Lake bed fauna includes more than 50 species dominated by freshwater [[Gastropoda|gastropods]] (''[[Hippeutis complanatus]]''), [[Trichoptera|Caddisflies]] (''[[Somatochlora metallica]]''), [[beetle]]s, and [[leech]]es (''[[Alboglossiphonia heteroclita]]''). Additionally, in 1969 a freshwater [[jellyfish]] (''[[Craspedacusta sowerbii]]'') was documented in the lake, a continental species then new to Sweden but not found in the lake since.<ref name="vattenprogram-15.5" />
Fishes natural to Långsjön include [[perch]], [[northern pike]], [[Rutilus|roach]], [[rudd]], [[carp bream]], [[crucian carp]], [[tench]], and [[ruffe]]; extraneous species are [[common carp]] and [[mirror carp]]. Pike and [[zander]] are planted-out carnivorous species while roach and crucian carp have been decimated by trawling. Sample catches in 1999 showed the number of perch, roach, and carp had increased far beyond expected levels. [[Crayfish plague]] hit the lake in 1984, but the [[signal crayfish]] was reintroduced within a few years.<ref name="vattenprogram-15.5" />
The lake is a breeding ground for most birds common to the Stockholm-area — such as [[mute swan]], [[mallard]], and [[Eurasian coot]] — and some less common — such as [[common moorhen]] and [[great crested grebe]]. Other bird sightings include [[Ardea (genus)|heron]], [[tufted duck]], [[common tern]], [[common pochard|pochard]], and [[spotted crake]].<ref name="vattenprogram-15.5" />
The lake is one of the most important breeding grounds for [[amphibians]], with a documented presence of [[common frog]], [[common toad]] and [[smooth newt]].<ref name="vattenprogram-15.5" />
== See also == * [[Geography of Stockholm]] * [[Lakes of Sweden]]

'''MSAT''', short for '''''Mobile Satellite''''', is a [[satellite]]-based [[mobile telephony]] service developed by the [[National Research Council of Canada]]. Supported by a number of companies in the [[United States|US]] and Canada, MSAT hosts a number of services, including the broadcast of [[CDGPS]] signals. The [https://web.archive.org/web/20110604025340/http://www.boeing.com/defense-space/space/bss/factsheets/601/msat/msat.html MSAT satellites] were built by Hughes (now owned by [[Boeing]]) with a 3 kilowatt solar array power capacity and sufficient fuel for a design life of twelve years. TMI Communications of Canada referred to its MSAT satellite as MSAT-1, while American Mobile Satellite Consortium (now [[Ligado Networks]]) referred to its MSAT as AMSC-1, with each satellite providing backup for the other.
==History== * April 7, 1995 - MSAT-2 (a.k.a. AMSC-1) launched from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]], Launch Complex 36, Pad A, aboard [[Atlas II|Atlas IIA]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.floridatoday.com/maps/launches/LC36Launches.htm |title=Florida Today Space and Missile Launch Database |accessdate=2006-11-26 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070317031734/http://www.floridatoday.com/maps/launches/LC36Launches.htm |archivedate=2007-03-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * May 1995 - testing causes overheating and damage to one of eight hybrid matrix amplifier output ports aboard MSAT-2<ref name="q1-1996">{{cite web|url=http://yahoo.brand.edgar-online.com/fetchFilingFrameset.aspx?FilingID=503983&Type=HTML|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930183504/http://yahoo.brand.edgar-online.com/fetchFilingFrameset.aspx?FilingID=503983&Type=HTML|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2007-09-30|title=AMERICAN MOBILE SATELLITE CORPORATION AND SUBSIDIARIES: Form 10-Q|date=2006-05-14|accessdate=2006-11-27}} </ref> * April 20, 1996 - MSAT-1 launched from [[Kourou, French Guiana]] aboard [[Ariane (rocket)|Ariane 42P]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.conveyor.com/space/news/can-space-5-96.html |title=MSAT-1 TO LAUNCH APRIL 20TH |accessdate=2006-11-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060624011242/http://www.conveyor.com/space/news/can-space-5-96.html |archivedate=2006-06-24 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boeing.com/defense-space/space/bss/launch/launched2.html |title=Boeing: Chronology of Launches |accessdate=2006-11-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061207023502/http://www.boeing.com/defense-space/space/bss/launch/launched2.html |archivedate=2006-12-07 |df= }}</ref> * May 15, 1996 - Reported failures of two solid state power amplifiers (SSPAs) and one L-band receiver on separate occasions aboard MSAT-2.<ref name="q1-1996" /> * May 4, 2003 - MSAT-1 loses two power amplifiers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdgps.com/e/cdgps_documents/Service%20Outage-2003-11-30.pdf |title=Service Outage - November 30, 2003 |accessdate=2006-11-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928143518/http://www.cdgps.com/e/cdgps_documents/Service%20Outage-2003-11-30.pdf |archivedate=2007-09-28 |df= }}</ref>
==Phaseout== MSAT-1 and MSAT-2 have had their share of problems. Mobile Satellite Ventures placed the AMSC-1 satellite into a 2.5 degree [[inclined orbit]] operations mode in November 2004, reducing station-keeping fuel usage and extending the satellite's useful life.<ref name="MOTIENT-CORP-Nov-2005-S-1">{{cite web|url=http://edgar.secdatabase.com/1313/121465905001601/filing-main.htm |title=MOTIENT CORP, Form S-1, Filing Date Nov 3, 2005 |publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate =May 14, 2018}}</ref>
On January 11, 2006, Mobile Satellite Ventures (MSVLP) (now [[LightSquared]]) announced plans to launch a new generation of satellites (in a 3 satellite configuration) to replace the MSAT satellites by 2010. MSV has said that all old MSAT gear would be compatible with the new satellites.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msvlp.com/media/press-releases-view.cfm?id=84&yr=2006 |title=Mobile Satellite Ventures Engages Boeing To Develop Next Generation Satellites |accessdate=2006-11-26 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061114162533/http://www.msvlp.com/media/press-releases-view.cfm?id=84&yr=2006 |archivedate=2006-11-14 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msvlp.com/investor/fact-sheet.cfm |title=Company Fact Sheet: Investor/Financial |accessdate=2006-11-26 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061114162616/http://www.msvlp.com/investor/fact-sheet.cfm |archivedate=2006-11-14 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * MSV-1 (U.S.) * MSV-2 (Canada) * MSV-SA (South America)
==Services Delivered via MSAT== The following services are singularly dependent upon the continued operation of the MSAT satellite: * [[CDGPS]] - a differential correction signal system for improved GPS navigation accuracy * Trailer Tracking - by [[SkyWave Mobile Communications]] * Trailer Tracking - by [[Skybitz|SkyBitz]] * EMERGNET - by [[Glentel]]
== See also == * [[Mobile-satellite service]] * [[Satellite phone]]
==References== <references />
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120204191258/http://www.msvlp.com/ Mobile Satellite Ventures] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110604025340/http://www.boeing.com/defense-space/space/bss/factsheets/601/msat/msat.html Mobile Satellite System for Canada, U.S.] * [http://www.mobilsat.com/Mobile-satellite-TV/ Mobile Satellite Systems]
{{Canadian Space Agency}}

revision.text:
[[File:Mokhotlong-Centre-and-Airport-2009.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Mokhotlong centre and airport]] [[File:LS-Mokhotlong.png|thumb|right|250px|Location of Mokhotlong in Lesotho]] '''Mokhotlong''' is a city and seat of [[Mokhotlong District]] in the mountainous northeastern part of [[Lesotho]]. It is the first major city with an airport along the road from South Africa across the [[Sani Pass]], near the Maloti ([[Drakensberg]] in [[South Africa]]) Mountains. The name of the city is a word in [[Sesotho]], the language of the people of Lesotho, meaning "Place of the Bald Ibis." [[Thabana Ntlenyana]], the highest point in southern Africa is found in Mokhotlong.
== History == Mokhotlong’s role as a police post first brought people to this part of Lesotho in 1905. It developed into a trading center for the people of the Highlands region. However, it was preserved from major development by its separation from the rest of the country. Not until 1947 was radio contact established with [[Maseru]], the capital city.
In the next few years an air strip was built and a road cleared through town to link Mokhotlong to the rest of Lesotho. Even so, Mokhotlong continued to be outfitted with provisions and supplies by pony trek from [[Natal Province|Natal, South Africa]], via Sani Pass.<ref name="The Rough Guide South Africa, Lesotho, & Swaziland">{{cite book|last=McCrea, Mthembu-Salter, Pinchuck, Reid|title=South Africa, Lesotho, & Swaziland: The Rough Guide|year=1999|publisher=Penguin Books Ltd.|location=London|isbn=1-85828-460-0|pages=644–646}}</ref>
== Geography and climate== An hour and a half drive north of Sani Pass, Mokhotlong is located 270 km from Maseru and 200 km from [[Butha-Buthe]]. The source of the [[Senqu River]], Lesotho’s largest river, is near Mokhotlong, impacting the landscape throughout the town and surrounding district.<ref name="Lonely Planet South Africa, Lesotho, & Swaziland 3rd Ed">{{cite book|last=Murray, Williams, Everist|title=South Africa, Lesotho, & Swaziland|year=1998|publisher=Lonely Planet|location=Hawthorn, Australia|isbn=0-86442-508-2|pages=609–610}}</ref>
Mokhotlong experiences a [[subtropical highland climate]] ([[Köppen climate classification]] ''Cwb'') with warm summers and cool, dry winters. {{Weather box |location = Mokhotlong |single line = Y |metric first = Y
|Jan high C = 24 |Feb high C = 23 |Mar high C = 21 |Apr high C = 18 |May high C = 15 |Jun high C = 12 |Jul high C = 13 |Aug high C = 15 |Sep high C = 18 |Oct high C = 19 |Nov high C = 22 |Dec high C = 22 |year high C =
|Jan low C = 12 |Feb low C = 11 |Mar low C = 10 |Apr low C = 6 |May low C = 2 |Jun low C = -1 |Jul low C = -2 |Aug low C = 1 |Sep low C = 5 |Oct low C = 8 |Nov low C = 9 |Dec low C = 11 |year low C =
|precipitation colour = green |Jan precipitation mm = 111 |Feb precipitation mm = 81 |Mar precipitation mm = 74 |Apr precipitation mm = 37 |May precipitation mm = 12 |Jun precipitation mm = 9 |Jul precipitation mm = 6 |Aug precipitation mm = 16 |Sep precipitation mm = 33 |Oct precipitation mm = 59 |Nov precipitation mm = 78 |Dec precipitation mm = 85 |year precipitation mm=
|source 1 = Climatedata.eu<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.climatedata.eu/climate.php?loc=ltzz0009&lang=en | title = Climate Mokhotlong - Lesotho | publisher = | accessdate = May 6, 2013 }}</ref> |date=May 2013 }}
== Events and activities == The mountain range is host to activities including hiking trails, horse trails, rock climbing, white water rafting, fly and trout fishing, golfing, bird and game watching, safaris, and much more.<ref name="South Africa: Discover Our Drakensberg">{{cite web|title=South Africa: Discover Our Drakensberg|url=http://www.drakensberg-tourism.com/|accessdate=7/6/2011}}</ref>
In addition to regular activities, Mokhotlong hosts the annual High Altitude Summer Marathon at the end of the year. The route runs through the Maloti Mountains and is characterized by great views of both mountains and villages. At 3000 meters above sea level, if the scenery does not take the runner’s breath away, the steep ascents and descents will. There are also half marathon and 10k events, in addition to the full marathon.
Mokhotlong is also on the route of the annual Roof of Africa Rally, an off-road motorcycle rally. Finally, Mokhotlong is home to the highest-elevated diamond mine in the world, [[Letseng diamond mine]], which can be toured, and is often frequented by local students as part of their course of study. Its diamonds have the highest per carat price of any [[kimberlite]] mine, and with the capacity to process more than 5 million tonnes a year and recover about 100,000 carats, it is the seventh largest in the world. Three of their diamonds are among the world’s top twenty rough diamonds.
== Socio-economy ==
Mokhotlong's economy is primarily driven by livestock rearing and subsistence [[agriculture]], though neither of these fully supports most families. Arable land in this mountainous region is a scarce resource. Agricultural production only sustains families from 3 to 9 months of the year. Families cover the gap largely through livestock and remittances from employed family members. However, livestock distribution is skewed with 60% of the livestock owned by 10% of the population; approximately 35% of the community have no livestock. General income is small, given both poor educational opportunities and the high unemployment rate in Lesotho and in South Africa. Consequently, a large segment of the population is seriously poor.<ref name="GROW Annual Reports: 1997-98, 1999-2000, 2000-2001">GROW Annual Reports: 1997-98, 1999-2000, 2000-2001</ref> This is exacerbated by HIV/AIDS, which ravages the region. Despite its poverty, few aid organizations work in Mokhotlong. Touching Tiny Lives provides nutritional and medical support to vulnerable children. GROW works with villages to increase agricultural production, support OVC households to improve livelihoods, capacity building, climate change adaptation strategies, etc.
In Mokhotlong City, the Mokhotlong district capital, formal employment is boosted by the presence of government offices.
== References == {{Reflist}} {{Refbegin}} {{Refend}}
